titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Finding aid prepared by Anne Harney. Revised by Friederike Baer (NEH 2010)

note.p: c. 150 items in the collection (B F867) are currently not described individually.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-13T19:27-0400

did.abstract: The letters to Persifor Frazer cover primarily matters related to geology and mineralogy. A portion of the correspondence, principally from British scientists, concerns the 1884 meeting in Philadelphia of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (B F867).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains 213 manuscript items, 4 pamphlets, 1 broadside, 6 newspaper clippings and 1 calling card. They are dated between 1882 and 1906. Most of the material is in English, but there are also a few items in French and German. A typed table of contents is included in the box.

Many of the manuscript letters (156) are correspondence from various persons, mostly British, to Persifor Frazer, pertaining to the 1884 meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, which was held in Philadelphia. All were written between June and September of 1884.

A good number of the items reflect Frazer’s interest in mineralogy and geology. They include a sizeable body of letters from Thomas Sterry Hunt, as well as the letters by James Hall and Joseph Leidy. They concern the examination of specimens, relevant publications, and the correspondents’ research. The letters by James Geikie tend to focus on current events and personal matters; they often have a light tone (as in the letter of October 14, 1885, which begins “My dear Chieftain” and goes on to tell Frazer about Geikie’s trip to the Highlands, where he indulged “in bagpipe music, whiskey, venison, and flirtations with the ladies”).

The collection also includes several letters by Ernst Heinrich Haeckel, all in German. Several of them refer to Haeckel’s book Weltraethsel. Also included is a letter in which Haeckel informs Frazer of his inability to attend the celebrations in honor of the 200th anniversary of Franklin’s birthday, held at the APS in 1906.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: For papers of his father John Fries Frazer, see B F865. For papers of his grandfather Robert Frazer, see B F868.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: C. 150 items were purchased and accessioned, 1957 (1957 731ms). Other accession numbers and dates: 1957 156ms (2 items; formerly B F867.1; B F867.2); 1958 2254ms (1 item; formerly B F867.3); 1958 2255ms (1 item; formerly B F867.4); 1958 2256ms (1 item; formerly B F867.5); 1958 2257ms (1 item; formerly B F867.6); 1958 2258ms (1 item; formerly B F867.7); 1958 2259ms (1 item; formerly B F867.8); 1958 2260ms; (48 items; Letters from various persons, 1883-1885; formerly B F867.9).

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Persifor Frazer (1844–1909, APS 1872) was a geologist and handwriting expert. He participated in geological surveys for the United States and for Pennsylvania and, after 1870, held the chair in chemistry at the University of Pennsylvania. He also published a manual on handwriting and, as a specialist in the identification of forged documents, served as an expert witness in several high profile trials. Persifor Frazer, also known as Persifor, Jr., was the only son of the Philadelphia scientist and educator John Fries Frazer (1812–1872, APS 1842) and his wife Charlotte Cave Frazer. He attended private schools before enrolling at the University of Pennsylvania, receiving his B.A. in 1862.

Frazer enlisted in the Union Army at the beginning of the Civil War. He served in the United States Coast Survey and was assigned to a South Atlantic squadron under Samuel F. DuPont (1803-1865, APS 1862). Later, he volunteered to fight in the Gettysburg campaign; and in 1864 became the acting ensign attached to the Mississippi Squadron. In 1865, after his honorable discharge, Frazer was granted a semi-honorary A.M. degree from the University of Pennsylvania.

Frazer studied chemistry in Philadelphia for six months before enrolling in the Royal Saxon School of Mines in Freiburg, Germany. He remained there for three years, focusing on the study of mineralogy and related subjects. In 1869 he was selected to serve as mineralogist and metallurgist to the United States Geological Survey, led by Ferdinand V. Hayden. In this capacity, he completed a report on Mining and Mineralogy of Colorado and Wyoming. In 1870 he became an instructor at the University of Pennsylvania; the next year he succeeded his father as Professor of Chemistry.

In 1874 Frazer resigned from his faculty position to join the Second Geological Survey of Pennsylvania, under the leadership of J. Peter Lesley (1819-1903, APS 1856). During his eight years with the Survey, he published a highly regarded report primarily on the southeastern counties of the state. In 1881 Frazer was the General Manager of the Central Virginia Iron Company. He was a founder of the American Geologist which he edited from 1888 to 1905. In 1889 he accepted an appointment as Professor of Chemistry of the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society. Two years later he became the Chair of Chemistry at the Franklin Institute. Frazer was a member of the American committee at the International Congress of Geologists three times: in Berlin (1885), London (1888), and St. Petersburg (1897). He also worked as a consulting metallurgist, geologist and mining engineer. In this capacity he traveled to different places in North America and abroad.

In later years, Frazer turned his attention to the study of handwriting, and soon became a widely respected expert in the field. In the course of his studies, he visited Aphonse Bertillon, the eminent French police officer and biometrics researcher. In 1894 Frazer published the highly regarded book A Manual for the Study of Documents (later re-titled Bibliotics; or, the Study of Documents …), which was intended to assist in the detection of forged handwriting. His main contribution to the field consisted in his recognition that fine tremors in handwriting could be detected under a microscope, and that these tremors were linked to the nerve state of the writer. A close comparison of tremors in different writing samples could help detect forgeries. Frazer’s expertise soon attracted the attention of lawyers. He was asked to serve as an expert witness in several high-profile trials, such as the 1899 murder trial of Roland B. Molineux of New York City. Based on his experiences in these trials, including his dismissal from a case for his refusal to swear to his belief in the existence of God, Frazer wrote the article "Expert Testimony: Its Uses and Abuses" (1902). In it he attacked the ways in which expert witnesses were generally treated by judges on the bench. The City of Philadelphia awarded him the John Scott Medal in 1906 for his invention of the colorimeter which measured the intensity and color value of ink in handwriting.

Frazer's scholarly output numbered around 300 titles. He also belonged to numerous learned and patriotic organizations. He was a founder of the Society of American Geologists and the Franklin Institute Journal. Other affiliations include, but are not limited to, the Academy of Natural Sciences, the Society of American Geologists, the Military Order of the Loyal Legion, the General and Pennsylvania Society of Sons of the Revolution, the Society of the War of 1812, the Society of Colonial Wars of Pennsylvania, the British Association for the Advancement of Science, the New York Academy of Science, and the Reichsanstalt of Vienna. He became a member of the American Philosophical Society in 1872, serving as its secretary from 1896 to 1898.

Persifor Frazer was married to Isabella Nevins Whelen. They had four children, three of whom lived to adulthood. He died on April 7, 1909, the day that the Pennsylvania State Senate passed a bill that allowed agnostics to testify as competent witnesses on affirmation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.D.S. 1p. Formerly B F867.2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lille, A.L.S. 1p.and add. In French. Sends his portrait. Formerly B F867.1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Montreal, A.L.S. 3p. (see P.Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Congratulates him on his thesis. Concerning geology. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: London, D. 1p. (see P.Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Tells him to stop his paper. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: New York, A.L.S. 4p. (see P.Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Concerning geology of New York. Asks that trousers he left behind be forwarded to him. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Montreal, A.L.S. 6p. Enc. (see P.Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Geology of New York. Geological matters. Concerning Geikie. For enclosure, see: Hunt to P.Frazer; May 16, [1883]. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Montreal, A.L.S. 2p. (see P. Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Concerning the meetings of the B.A.A.S. and the A.A.A.S. Concerning natural water. Enclosed originally in: same to same; May 16, 1883. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Montreal, A.L.S. 4p. (see P. Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Concerning the meeting of the American and British geologists. Concerning Geikie. Friendly letter. Concerning the Canadian royal society. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Montreal, A.L. 4p. Incomplete. (see P.Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Concerning geology. Concerning the A.A.A.S. Concerning Geikie. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks for arranging for rooms at the Continental, hopes to arrive for the opening of the meeting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 2 items: calling card (with "CB" and "FRS" added by hand) and a note declining the invitation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 2 items: envelope and note acknowledging hotel booking and inquiring whether he must pay expenses or if he is a guest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans to attend the meeting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans to attend and will advise the Continental Hotel what dates he will need his room.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been in contact with the hotel regarding her arrival date.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will be unable to attend as Mr. [Ailidge?] must return to England sooner than expected.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes to attend along with Dowling (a recent member of the B.A.A.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Appreciates the arrangements, arrival will now be delayed until the 7th or 8th.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets that he and his wife will not be able to attend the meeting as previously expected.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Travel and lodging arrangement at the Colonnade Hotel for Carver, his wife, and two daughters for the meeting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Traveling with his daughter, not wife; requests that this be corrected with the hotel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will arrive with a friend on Monday the 8th of September and requests assistance with lodging.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans to attend and will communicate directly with the Bellevue Hotel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets not seeing Frazer before his 8/28 departure, looks forward to seeing him in Philadelphia and has advised the Colonnade of his travel plans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 2 items: evelope and letter declining the invitation since, as an officer of the Association, he does not feel able to leave Montreal in time.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans to arrive in Philadelphia the following Thursday, and has advised the Contintental Hotel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Declines offer of hotel room as he cannot visit Philadelphia in time for the meeting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Declines offer of hosptiality for the Philadelphia meeting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans to attend with a different friend (not [Ailidge?]) and their arrival and departure times are not yet fixed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets missing Frazer in person, occupied with "the business of my Section "7"."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unsigned letter regarding "hospitality" offered in Philadelphia (e.g. who will pay visitors' room and board).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will be accepting Rev. E. Whitall's hospitality for the meeting in Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests a reply, references room 552.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans to attend the meeting, as does his son.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Written on behalf of Trail and his wife, who plan to attend the meeting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 4 items. Envelopes addressed to Persifor Frazer. Handwritten notes regarding senders (Briggs, Wrightson, McKendrick and Mrs. H. Binney Brown?) and replies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Discusses logistics (5:55 PM arrival on Friday), requests that tickets to the Presidential address be given to R. Pearsall Smith (his host in Philadelphia), advises of his intention to register the following morning.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hotel is unnecessary, after being invited to lodge with Dr. Levick.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Addresses apparent discrepancy in hotel reservations, announces plans to be at the Hotel Lafayette on Wednesday or Thursday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will be able to attend the meeting in Philadelphia, and requests accommodations for himself and his son.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Carver's son (Arthur Wellington Carver) will now also be coming to the meeting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans to attend the meeting, will accept offer of hospitality if it is still available.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans to attend the meeting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will not be able to attend the meeting because of an excursion to the Rocky Mountains.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Montreal, A.L.S. 3p. (see P.Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Has been ill. Will come to Philadelphia. Concerning geologists, among whom are James Hall and James Geikie. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Detailing travel plans to Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans to attend the meeting, requests a "good sized room with bath."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writing on behalf of his brother-in-law (Rev. H. W. [Coulson]?) who has been delayed in England and thus unable to attend the meeting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will be unable to attend the meeting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes to advise he has arrived in his hotel in Philadelphia (but, like some other travelers, his baggage has been delayed).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Philadelphia, A.L.S. 2p. (see P.Frazer Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Thanks him for a favor. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes to accept a dinner invitation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 2 items: calling card, letter complaining of the prices and service at the Continental Hotel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Boston, A.L.S. 2p. (see P.Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Asks that his mail be forwarded to Montreal. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Montreal, A.L.S. 6p. (see P.Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Friendly letter. Looks for asbestos mines. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 2 items: calling card ("The Master of St. John's College" is crossed out, and "Rev. C. Taylor DD." and "Cambridge, England" written by hand), and letter stating intent to attend the meeting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers thanks for hospitality while in Philadelphia, some details of his subsequent travels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Abstract of address before the Congress, per penciled note.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lt. Col.'s calling card, "Glasgow" added by hand.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Edinburgh A.L.S. 4p. (see P.Frazer. Lettres from various persons; 1883-1885.) Describes his work. Concerning current events in England. Friendly letter. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Montreal, A.L.S. 3p. (see P.Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Friendly letter. Concerning the study of mineralogy. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Montreal, A.L.S. 2p. (see P.Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Concerning his plans for travel. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Edinburgh A.L.S. 4p. (see P.Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Concerning his plans for the next few months. Sends doggerel verse on "To my Alma Mater on the completion of her 300th year." Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Boston, A.L.S. 3p. (see P.Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Concerning his travels. Glad the photograph was sent to Frazer. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ann Arbor, A.L.S. 4p. (see P.Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Concerning certain business of the A.A.A.S. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Edinburgh, A.L.S. 4p. (see P.Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Is delighted that he is in England, but cannot see him until October. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Edinburgh A.L.S. 2p. (see P.Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Looks forward to his visit the latter part of October. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 1p. (see P.Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Wants him to come and visit. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A.L.S. 3p. (see P.Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Is sorry that they could not meet. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Philadelphia, A.L.S. 2p. (see P.Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Is sorry that, due to ill health, he cannot visit Frazer. Formerly B F867.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: New York, A.L.S. 1p. (see Persifor Frazer papers. No.4.) Asks for some information. Concerning his paper on mineralogy. Formerly B F867.4.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: New York, A.L.S. 3p. (see Persifor Frazer papers. No. 3.) Thanks for, and praises of , his publication on mineralogy. Will soon send his new publication. Formerly B F867.3.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Baden-Baden, A.L.S.on postal card. 1p.and add. In German. (see Persifor Frazer papers. No. 5.) FILM 403 FRAME 110. Formerly B F867.5.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Jena, A.L.S. 2p.and add. In German. (see Persifor Frazer papers. No. 8.) FILM 403 FRAME 111. Formerly B F867.8.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Jena, A.L.S. 2p.and add. In German. (see Persifor Frazer papers. No. 7.) FILM 403 FRAME 112. Formerly B F867.7.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Jena, A.L.S. 3p.and add. In German.(see Persifor Frazer papers. No. 6.) Concerning the 200th anniversary of Franklin. Refers to the APS. FILM 403 FRAME 113. Formerly B F867.6.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thursday. A.L.S.with initials. (see P.Frazer. Letters from various persons; 1883-1885.) Concerning the list of persons for candidates. Concerning a publication on obelisks. Formerly B F867.9.
